isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 5000 9100 9200 9400 9900 MODELS BUILT OCTOBER 1, 1998 AND AFTER - GAUGES AND WARNING LIGHTS - 5000, 5000i, 9000, 9000i - OPERATION - REAR AXLE AND TRANSMISSION TEMPERATURE GAUGES

svcproc.title: REAR AXLE AND TRANSMISSION TEMPERATURE GAUGES
svcproc.para: The optional (forward or rear) rear axles and transmission oil temperature gauges are 3-pin electrical gauges. The gauges are located in the right gauge cluster and they all receive ignition voltage at connector (420) terminal 3, circuit 28C, from 10A fuse F4-A. The cluster contains a printed circuit board which the rear axle and transmission oil temperature gauges plug into.

The "I" gauge terminal for these three gauges receives ignition voltage through the cluster. The "G" gauge terminal of these three gauges is grounded through the circuit board and cluster connector (420) on circuits 11-GJ/11-GQ/11-GF at the ground stud located at the left dash.
The "S" gauge terminal of these gauges is connected to the gauge sender as follows:

step1.para: The "S" terminal of the forward rear axle gauge is connected through connector (420) terminal 20 to the gauge sender. The gauge sender is grounded through the axle housing, which is grounded through circuit 32-G to J4 cab ground.

The "S" terminal of the rear rear axle gauge is connected through connector (420) terminal 19 to the gauge sender. The gauge sender is grounded through the axle housing, which is grounded through circuit 32-GA to J4 cab ground.

The "S" terminal of the transmission gauge is connected through connector (420) terminal 18 to the gauge sender. The transmission gauge sender is grounded through circuit 31-G to the engine ground stud.

svcproc.para: The temperature gauge sender for the axle and transmission acts like a variable resistor. When the oil temperature is high, resistance is LOW and when the oil temperature is low, resistance is HIGH. The change in circuit resistance provides the input to the gauge.
